Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Stereoselective Polymerization Catalysis of Biomass Monomers by Chiral Transition-Metal and Organic Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program and the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division support the project by Professor Eugene Chen. Professor Chen is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University. He is developing new methods of chemical catalysis for the synthesis of new types of plastics (polymers). These new plastics are renewable, meaning that they are prepared from grown feedstocks, and thus are sustainable. The second feature of these new polymers is that they have regular and well-controlled (stereoregular) chemical structures. Plastics with these characteristics have better physical properties for many applications. These two properties, stereoregularity and renewability, are important for new applications of plastics in the modern economy. The proposed research encompasses diverse areas of chemistry, materials science, and sustainability, thereby providing an excellent opportunity for training and teaching of students, including underrepresented minorities and undergraduate students.

The proposed study addresses three currently unmet challenges still facing both the metal catalyzed and organocatalyzed polymerizations of acrylic monomers. First, existing chiral metal catalysts show high stereoselectivity in the polymerization of linear, petroleum-based acrylics but lack of stereochemical control over the polymerization of biomass-derived compact cyclic acrylics. Hence, the first specific objective of the work is to design advanced chiral transition-metal catalysts, assisted by theory, to enable stereoselective polymerization of such challenging bio-derived cyclic acrylic monomers. Second, the recently developed organocatalyzed proton-transfer polymerization can convert diacrylics uniquely into biodegradable unsaturated polyesters, but the current polyester product is an amorphous non-crystalline material, thus limiting its application. Accordingly, the second specific objective of the work is to develop the stereoselective proton-transfer polymerization for the synthesis of stereoregular crystalline unsaturated polyesters. Third, the current organocatalytic conjugate-addition polymerization of acrylic monomers produces only achiral acrylic polymers. Thus, the third specific objective of the work is to establish asymmetric organopolymerization of acrylic monomers to produce optically active chiral polymers. The education plan includes training and teaching of a diverse study body with complementary experimental and computational methods employed in this catalytic chemistry research, as well as for educating students and the general public about the central role of chemistry in addressing the global sustainability challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central objective of this project is to develop new stereoselective polymerization methods or processes using chiral transition-metal and organic catalysts for the synthesis of high-value stereoregular and crystalline polymers from biomass-derived, oxygen-rich renewable monomers. This research has potential to positively impact our society, as this work employs catalytic polymerization methods for advanced and sustainable polymers, two areas essential to modern life and the global economy. In addition, the proposed research encompasses diverse areas of chemistry, materials science, and sustainability, thereby providing an excellent opportunity for training and teaching of students, including underrepresented students.

Centering on this central objective, our studies have yielded the following five significant project results. First, the novel diastereoselective polymerization methodology enabled by specifically designed chiral catalysts can directly polymerize racemic/meso mixtures of cyclic diolide monomers carrying two stereogenic centers into stereo-sequenced crystalline polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) with isotactic and syndiotactic stereo-diblock or stereo-tapered block microstructures. This method not only avoids the need for separation and purification of monomer?s diastereomers before polymerization and loss of materials as a result, it also utilizes all diastereomers of the monomer for construction of unique stereo-sequenced crystalline PHAs. Second, biodegradable PHA materials can be designed to exhibit robust polyolefin-like thermal and mechanical properties, through engineering of polymers? copolymer composition, sequence, and stereomicrostructure enabled by specifically designed chiral molecular catalysts. Third, designer chemically recyclable copolymers can be utilized as packaging materials with desired mechanical and barrier properties, plus an advantage by exhibiting intrinsic chemical circularity. Fourth, a strategy for establishing a closed-loop polymer upcycling process has been developed by designing a cost-effective upcycling scheme, discovering property-enhancing structures and, most importantly, installing recyclability into upcycled plastics to enable a circular lifecycle. Fifth, an infinitely recyclable plastic with practically useful thermal and mechanical properties has been discovered based on a six-five fused bicyclic lactone, racemic trans-hexahydrophthalide, which has been achieved by the stereoselective polymerization of the lactone with a metal-based catalyst under a low catalyst loading (20 ppm) and ambient-temperature, solvent-free conditions.

Key research findings of this study have been disseminated to the general public through 16 peer-refereed publications acknowledging this NSF support, and through seminars or lectures before academic, industrial, and international audiences. The current NSF support resulted in the employment, training and education of seven graduate students and postdoctoral fellows with technical skills needed for carrying out modern research in their future careers in chemical sciences; four of the project trainees belong to an underrepresented group (women).


Last Modified: 10/31/2020
Modified by: Eugene Y Chen
